I do not prefer online class as I miss the study environment, going to school allows me to tell me teacher in person about the issues I'm facing with the assignment. Having face to face in person is better as I'm able to access resources that I need from school that I dont have at home such as a printer , textbooks group activities that can help with learning and understanding the task that's been give. Having face to face in a school environment allows me to focus more on my work and creates and environment were I do feel more motivated and determined. 
However, having to stay at home has been a pain not just for my learning but for mental health and focus. Which is why I prefer face to face as theres so much school/teachers can provide that online classes cant as are teachers aren't always available in this isolation thing which cause students to have to halt their work as they may be confused however, having an one to one class in person with the teacher allows the student to ask the teacher any questions when they are struggling with their work. To conclude I prefer face to face as it create and environment of work ethics and allows students to ask questions at any time as the teacher is present in classes at all time. Thank u for your time.

column17: There are definitely pros and cons. I live in a rural area approx. 300km from Adelaide, South Australia where I attend university (& live during the semester), so have enjoyed having the flexibility of working from my family home. However, I have found it difficult to adjust to online learning, as I feel the content was not designed for this setting. It has made it more difficult to engage with content and I've felt more isolated with my learning experiences. Online classes that have breakout rooms and discussion have been more rewarding and enjoyable experiences, but some of my courses aren't utilising the technology effectively (if that makes sense). Thank you for doing this research and please keep us updated on your findings xx

column16: Our lecturers and professors still expect a similar level of enthusiasm and commitment to discussion, and given the circumstances and the nature of the platform, I find this difficult to achieve. For example, in a Roman Literature seminar I took online, discussion was limited due to people’s wifi connection. Consequently, when our discussion was therefore not as detailed as usual, the lecturer seemed frustrated with our input. This has happened on multiple occasions. I feel as though online seminars etc. should not be conducted online in a video conference, perhaps a running chat or forum type element would work more effectively.

column16: My professors are really trying to make classes engaging and utilize every resource they can but sometimes technology is more limiting than liberating
column17:
In-person. Educators can support students better when they are physically present in class. For e.g. breakout groups on zoom students can still participate in group work but the professor can't just jump in when they overhear something interesting or a problem/question. 
A lot of creative assignments we did in class are also not possible because you need objects or arts & crafts material. The same goes for research we did outside of class that required material which is not available online. Let alone STEM classes with lab components or theatre/arts classes. 
My online language classes also just don't compare to in-person classes. People end up cutting each other off, pronounciation exercises are much more difficult, plus the professor can't immediately correct grammatical mistakes because they would have to cut someone off or due to them not being able to monitor all breakout rooms at once.

column16: My seminars have been transformed into us typing our responses to the seminar questions/exercises/readings on a document that we can all access, however I would prefer them to take place via a video call. Whilst the quality of responses has been high -possibly due to students being able to take their time to collect their thoughts and articulate a response, which isn’t always possible in a back and forth face to face discussion-, the quantity has been very low. The idea of having to articulate and write out our thoughts on the content for everyone to see may be off putting, meaning a lower volume of replies which limits how far students can engage with other viewpoints. Holding seminars via a video call may mitigate anxiety that students may have about writing responses for everyone to see whilst also bringing about a conversation in which students can ‘bounce ideas off of each other’.
column17: I prefer in-person classes as I believe conversations about the topics take place more naturally, meaning that they may be of a higher quality. I also find that the learning environment being on campus and attending in-person classes provides is more conducive of good learning than being at home and taking online classes, especially as there is no desk space available for me to work at at home.

Online classes are better for two reasons:
1. You choose the environment that you work in, which can make study comfortably and be more motivated 
2. It gives chances for students who are afraid to speak up to ask questions, give their opinions and take initiative to answer something due the fact that there is no one to judge them. I noticed this in my experience in online courses in a way that mnay students who were usually quite in class were actively participating in online courses

column17: Yes I definitely do! Online classes are a good way for shy students to embrace themselves and to show their actual knowledge. With the possibility of homeschooling I neither have a long transfer to school (45 minutes to school and back) nor do I have to stress myself if I can’t follow my teacher or if a class bores me. column17: I truly prefer in-person classes because one can experience the university's atmosphere, meet new people and explore new places. In class, teachers can better understand if we, the students, are picking up on the subject or if we are struggling and it provides students with the tools to develop the skills associated with their degree, if someone is enrolled in a scientific degree it is very much impossible that they can do the laboratory work online, for example. Being a Political Science and International Relations student, my friends and I debate this subject quite often and we came to the conclusion that we don't see online schooling as being a fair system because it leaves some students behind. It is not fair, or even democratic, that a student who, back home doesn't have good WiFi connection and a fast computer, can't keep up with the amount of work this system demands. No one can guarantee that every student has the living conditions to have a safe and quiet space to study and do university work, no one should be left behind.

column17:
As a student who’s intending to major in Mathematics, I find online classes better , since Im(in case of recorded lectures) I get to rewind what I don’t understand ; however, when it comes to classes that involve  participation ,like a Sociology class, i.e. “Social Class and Inequality” , I think in-person classes are much better , since engagement is one-to-one and debates arise easily in a class - platform.
So overall, I’d say that in-person classes are better since they are more engaging and they tend to motivate the person to think on the spot, from my point of view.

It is to be noted that in my University, we use various platforms for communication .
( Zoom , recorded lectures, PowerPoints, and discussion boards on a site called “blackboard”)

column8: In-class assessments/quizzes, Videos, Asking students to explain concepts to the class, Small group activities where you solve a problem together, Role playing situations, Asking you to apply class material to a new context, Im studyin at Erasmus University Rotterdam and we use a method of teaching called Problem Based Learning. Through this method we are given learning goals prior to our class discussion (e.g. What is ADHD?) which we have to research on our own. Our class discussion are usually 3 hours long and during them we discuss the literature we have read. Our groups consist of 10-12 students and a tutor. The students are the ones that facilitate the discussion, while the tutor has very minimal input and is there mainly to supervise and to make sure we don't miss any crucial information.
column16: I don't think I would change anything. Even though this a rather new environment for my university and it slightly limits the efficacy of the PBL method, I believe my university is handling the classes very well.
column17: To some extent I think I prefer them more as they give me more comfort, whereas due to our teaching method sometimes I feel inferior in live classes. However, in the same time online classes give me the opportunity to participate less in class when I haven't researched a topic well enough and I either don't have the right information, haven't remember it sufficiently or I just don't understand it, which takes from the quality of my studying and doesn't help me understand the topic as well as when I'm made to participate in the discussion.

column17:
I prefer in person classes as there is mingling and networking before during and after with fellow students as well as the professors.
I enjoy the independence and freedom we all get from online classes, yet I miss the personal touch and embodied presence that comes with in person experience of life. 
I believe although online classes are a huge opportunity, they will never be able to replace an embodied learning experience where people are physically in the same space. I live the co-creation unfolding in these moments.

column17: I prefer online classes because I suffer with a lot of health problems (cramps all the time and anxiety) which sometimes makes it super hard to attend classes and give them 100% of my attention. Being at home makes it a lot easier and I don't have to stress about missing a class because of a problem teachers don't understand as I don't have any medical justification. As to being productive, I am way more productive at home scheduling my time to do every little thing than at physical uni (I'd have to get in the car/wait for the bus, attend class, then come home and do all the tasks like cooking and cleaning, then study and do all of my uni projects in the middle of all this, having almost 0 time to myself and would make me exhausted at the end of the day). I think I enjoy classes at home because I can listen to the teachers and fully comprehend the classes (if I don't understand anything I am less shy to ask it via chat than in person).

But given the circumstances, we’re all doing our best and the online classes are still much better than the alternative, which in suppose is nothing at all.

column16: I would definitely prefer it if all teacher were doing online lectures (as some only send PowerPoints with voice recording). It is much more engaging and seeing everyone's faces gives you that sense of community (however, it could never replace their real presence). I wish it was more interactive, but I understand that teachers were not trained for this kind of learning and they don't all have resources to give video conferences/ some of them have children or people to take care of at home.
column17: No. I prefer in-person classes because the you get to be surrounded by other students and the teacher has the ability to make the class engaging (ex: we can get in groups, solve problems on the board,etc.). There is also the extracurricular activities that I miss. My school has over 100 student clubs and participating in talks, workshops, and shows could never be done online. On another note, I do enjoy the flexibility that online classes offer me. As most of the learning is done asynchronously, you get to manage your time however you want. This allows for living with more intentionality and in a way, being productive because YOU made the choice to be is sooo fulfilling!

Personally, I am also a lot calmer in my own space rather than in a large lecture hall. I can create my own environment.

column16: I would change the algorithm as it would be highly convenient if we could be assessed on an individual basis via personal chatrooms or video assessments. The reason for this is because it would make it easier for professors to mark accordingly and structurally; much like how students' university applications are at times reviewed on an individual basis.
column17: My cohort and I have only started using online based classes recently so I cannot make a concluding judgement as it is too soon to decide. However, there are many aspects of remote teaching that intrigue and fascinate me i.e. research tasks and assignments, remote teamwork by group chats and timed feedback from students. However, distant learning can definitely be more strenuous as communication is not always efficient and immediate whereas with face to face classes, queries and words overall can be articulated better and some people like myself do prefer verbal feedback over written feedback. Although, I believe that online teaching does aim to discipline students in a sense that we have to be strict with our time management.

column17: I do not prefer online classes, but I think it’s only because of the structure. I am part of a public school district, so they can’t disadvantage students who don’t have access to a device or high-speed internet. As such, our school week has been cut in more than half with little time to interact with each other. I do not feel like I’m learning unless I put in the effort to use outside sources. That said, I think I would enjoy online classes if the format was better. For math especially, it may be helpful to have a prerecorded lecture that I can watch again or rewind if I don’t initially understand. I have also been enjoying more free time and time with my family before I (hopefully) go to college next year!

column16: My uni is embracing the "academic approach" ah they call it lol.  I would prefer to be on campus and interacting with people face to face. We have heaps of group assignments which are really hard to coordinate when we can’t discuss in person. It’s also way harder/more intimidating to ask lecturers and tutors questions virtually as opposed to in person.

column17: I prefer in-person classes. I also think it’s easier for the teacher to understand who is grasping and understanding the lesson and who is confused. There is no way I’m going to say I’m confused with something online because I just get too anxious!! I’m really struggling with online classes, also I don’t have a lot of self confidence. I get on really well with my teachers and they motivate me to do well in class and put in effort outside of class, I’m not doing nearly enough work now that it’s online. Also change in environment is important and I can’t really do that!

column17:
No. 

1 - It is a lot more time consuming as I have to pause lecture recordings constantly to take notes which interrupts the flow of the lecture.

2 - The speed of the lecture recordings is way too fast and I therefore often find myself having to replay the same sentences over and over which also interrupts the flow of the lecture.

3 - It feels a lot less rewarding as it almost seems like the lectures are read from a script and are presented in a monotone and disengaging way. This was never the case with in person lectures regardless of how ‘boring’ the topic was.

However, being able to access all relevant information without having to physically attend has its advantages such as being able to listen to a recording when sick etc.

column17: My university was not designed with online classes in mind so I prefer in person classes as it provides more structure. Also online classes mean that valuable learning assessments can’t be conducted such as labs. As an engineering student having in person labs is necessary to develop real life skills relating to the material. Additionally, in person classes allow for final exams to be conducted fairly as there’s no way to proctor a final exam online without requiring students to purchase additional software. Furthermore, I don’t think it is ethical for professional degree programs such as medicine, nursing and engineering to be conducted online as these programs require students to develop skills through real life experience not just online assessments.

column17: Sometimes, sometimes not.  I prefer learning from home because it means I can concentrate more on what I need to concentrate on, and get on with work as opposed to wasting a class, which can sometimes happen in person.  I’m not distracted by classmates either.  I can send any questions in directly in an email, whenever I have one.  However, self-motivation at home is really difficult.  Also if I had particular trouble with anything I can see how it would be difficult to get through it on my own at home.  It’s easy to be disheartened by something and end up ignoring the problem.  Also, in-person classes and face-to-face hands-on teaching is essential for so many other things.  Communication is way more effective and engaging in class, if the teacher does it right.  Ironically, sometimes it can be better in online classes as the students aren’t distracted.  But it is more difficult to show videos, and we cannot do experiments etc.  There are benefits to both.  I don’t think any schooling system should be solely one or the other.

column8: Videos
column16:
In my case, online classes pretty much resume to the teacher just reading the slides or reading a pdf file. The only enjoyable class I have is for chemical kinetics, where the professor records himself writing and explaining (using a drawing tablet and a special program), and the only reason I like it is beacause he's the most wholesome person I've ever met. Otherwise, watching his videos and taking notes feels very time consuming and it's not that great for motivation. As for the others, honestly, I would like it if they just sent the course materials (pdf files or powerpoint presentations) without the zoom meetings. Personally, I find it a lot easier to just study on my own and look for explanations myself, because they most certainly don't explain things very well.
I wish we used an actual learning platform, like google classroom or moodle or something of the sort.
column17:
Absolutely not. First of all, I am a biochemistry major. Online classes means no labs. Labs are the core of anything related to chemistry, and it hinders the learning process tremendously. I would much rather go to in-person classes because I genuinely enjoy labs and experiments.
Second of all, online classes are very disorganised here. I wouldn't want them to be Minerva-style organized either, because Minerva classes rely way too much on actual participation, and it just gives me anxiety. I prefer just having the materials handed out and being left on my own to organize myself. But, at the same time, I would at least like to have a dedicated platform. The professors here use way too many different "platforms". Some use zoom, some use whatsapp groups, some send materials over by email (or both email and whatsapp), there's one lone professor who made a google classroom but gave us the wrong code (and she never bothered to send us the right one). It's tiring, to be honest.
There's also the fact that online classes feel very lonely. Disconnected. I liked going to class because I could sit with people I know, and we could laugh and work together on whatever it was that we had to do. I miss my lab partner, because we make a really good team and she honestly makes 3 hour long labs feel less draining. 
To sum up, the answer is absolutely not. Online classes aren't really for me, and I would much rather have in-person classes.

column5: I'm in 12th grade in Egypt, over here no one goes to school on our last year because it's an 'important' year and we need to get a good grade to be accepted in our desired uni. The ministry of education tried to fix the problem by changing the system of highschool which they did and now they have online content and exams but since I'm the last year of the old system I don't get a tablet from the ministry neither content for my education. Many people go to take private lessons which are usually houses/apartments that teachers rent rooms and give in it classes for the students and costs money but ever since the corona virus spread the government closed all those centers. Now i've been about 3 weeks self isolating but due to a lot of teachers having big audiences of students they are forced to upload content online and for free so i take use of that. Also there's and educational channel where they have specialised teachers in each subject explain everything we need, so I've been following them as well. Sorry for the long answer.

column16: Online classes would be more motivating and engaging if teachers knew how to use digital platforms better, as many of them have difficulties in conducting a lesson online without making several mistakes in one lesson (ex. column17: I much prefer in person classes, because you can more easily engage and participate in the lesson. You also have a better interaction with both your teacher and your classmates. column17: In person classes. My degree is modern languages and it's so important for teachers to be able to see everyone whilst they are speaking- if you hesitate as you're trying to remember a piece of vocab it's really hard to know whether it's a connection problem or if you are genuinely pausing to think. Also body language and facial expressions are so important in getting the 'gist' of a conversation in a foreign language. Whilst turning on video is an option, many students don't feel comfortable/confidential enough to do this as we're not at all used to this format yet.

A good system for who can speak when. Some teachers encourage everyone to speak up with questions or comments whenever they need to like they would in a normal setting, but because not everyone uses video this gets confusing, and it actually makes me less likely to speak up, as I’m afraid to be interrupting people.

They kept us engaged and called for discussuons that would not have happened had we not participated CCS. Of course there was backlash, where it just was not for a lot of people. But it was the head teachers baby and so they kept at it with us. Overall, online class gives us an excuse to slack off, there is no accountability (which kinda scares me because  I need something to keep me in check and motivated and online classes are so depressing, I hate doing the work it's so boring.

column16:
My online classes don’t involve video calls which is disappointing. I think it would be more interactive and students would engage more if a question is asked. Also, professional atmosphere is created because you see everyone else working and getting involved. 
Furthermore, online classes should mirror school classes (for us that’s a do now, teaching point, explanation, writing task). However, online classes fail to create the same structure which can take time to adapt to.
column17:
Person classes. This is because I associate the physical building of school with effort, challenges etc and it has been difficult to put the same effort in my online lessons as I would in school. Also, seeing teachers explain content in front of me is easier than on a recorded video. 
There’s a higher chance of people messing about in online lessons as they feel like there’s no punishment and as a result, the classes overall work ethic reduces.

column16: I think the main problem is that due to suddenly having to put the remainder of course teaching online, the prepared content/ structure of teaching is not designed for remote online engagement (i.e. lectures and tutorials). Adaptation to teaching online classes should take this into account and structure of class should be changed. For example, content should be given in advance (to read about what a formal lecture may have covered), then come together for discussion in class, online classes need to be more active than face to face lectures/tutorials etc
column17: I prefer in person classes as you have to be there and engaged and questions are easier to ask and get response from quickly than online, additionally connecting to peers is easier to do face to face. This last one has been a bit hard, some of my classmates had to talk to teachers to say that the classes were harder online, so they had to change their approach. column17:
They're equal in their own way. I love online classes because there's a lot of interaction (we share screens and fill in excel sheets together and stuff). However some teachers just read a powerpoint that they previously emailed us (same as when we had in-person classes). Some teachers use paper support that they gave us before the lockdown, that we all fill in together by hand or on Excel. The one negative point is that some people don't have wifi and have to use their phone data.
I dont think irl classes were much different. What I liked with irl school though and that I miss the most is actually seeing people and going out of the house.

column17: In-person classes. Even when I took an online class when there was no pandemic going on, I went to the live recording to keep myself accountable. I remember that we also had discussion in that class, but we used a special platform for about 20 minutes and we had a required number of contributions to make. The discussion leader would prompt discussion by asking questions related to a topic we had beforehand. We would also have to @ the person we were answering to. Personally I like live discussions in-person (or at least with Zoom) better because a) it takes me less time to speak than to type and b) It’s more manageable because not everyone is trying to input an answer at the same time and c) there are usually no rehires contributions. In any case, I think live discussions via zoom or in-person work better if it’s a group of about 20 people or less, like in my current classes. I also prefer smaller classes, so that may influence my opinion, too. I know that’s a lot but I hope that’s helpful...??? Good luck on your assignment!

column17: I think both have there own advantages but I am a little inclined towards in person classes. It is just that I feel you learn something new together as a group. I really miss the discussions and Q/A sessions which suffer a lot online because of internet issues sometimes or just because you are limited by the props you can use. I do think that a subject like science would benefit a lot from in person classes as things are a lot more hands on. While learning a new language, in person class we would generally use actions via our hands or facial expressions to remember new words or would play games which becomes hard to do during online classes.

column17: No, I prefer in-person class as I like to be able to connect with people more personally. I learn much better this way. Having a class all in one room makes debates and discussion far more engaging, compelling and lively. Additionally, they largely deter people from talking over each other. To me, online-classes seem a little robotic and strange; not being able to read a persons' body language makes it difficult to understand what they truly mean: words can only go so far. That being said, I am incredibly grateful in a time like now (COVID-19 crisis) that online teaching is available, and that I am privileged enough to engage with it. I also recognise the flexibility and potential online-classes have. They can educate people who do not have access to in-person teaching whether they live in a remote area; are in full-time work; house-bound because of illness, both mental or physical, or injury; or just because they want to learn a new skill without committing to a time or place. However, when given the option, in-person classes are always my choice, and I hope online-classes never fully replace face-to-face teaching - not least because the webcam camera angle is greatly unflattering.

I also prefer the company of my friends and fellow students when I am in class, and it is much easier to stay behind and chat about the lectures and so on. column17:
Pros and cons to both.
Online cons - not everyone has access to resources (maybe even a laptop/camera and microphone), technical problems, static sound etc. not everyone is user friendly with software. 
Online pros- can have meet ups whenever, wherever, lots of unique tools and devices on the software. 
In person pros - mentally more stimulating as can meet people, emotional connections with people, can read peoples faces better, debates are better as technical problems online over shouting out. 
In person cons - set to a place and time, work not always saved forever online, eg. A recorded lecture you can go back to.

Hope this gives some ideas :)

column16: It depends on the course. There are a few subjects where the method of teaching is exactly the same as it was before and it works perfectly. However there are a few of professors who just read straight from a power point and watching an online class or not is exactly the same. Sometimes it is also difficult to hear the professor correctly because of the sound which sometimes goes down due to WiFi errors. And this is completely understandable. There are a lot of people using Zoom or even WiFi networks. And nobody needs to be obliged to pay for a better service. However, there are a few professors who know this happens and do not make available the content that was given in a theoretical/practical class which is not good because if we do end up having online evaluations (for instance, final exams, another thing I am not to sure about) we need to have access to everything that was given.
column17: Again, it depends. As described before there are some which work the same way so in those cases online classes are good because it saves me the time of traveling to the faculty. column17:
I prefer in person classes. I have had a lot more time familiarizing myself with how to act in an in-person class and the online ones are unnatural and awkward. It is hard to stay focused and motivated, there are a ton of distractions from my family. Online classes feel like they are more work and it’s harder to be accountable. My professors are literally assigning us more work in classes that are already intensive. I spend a lot of time figuring out what I’m actually supposed to be doing instead of learning. 

I also feel that there is pressure to act dishonestly with online exams because my school has a very cutthroat culture and many classes are graded on a curve. I am strongly against cheating but I’m afraid that other students will cheat and skew the curve.

column17: there are good and bad sides to both. good thing for online classes: stay in comfy clothes, nice surroundings (your own room), enough space on the table (your own, clean, possibly large desk), you can be on your phone the whole time without the teacher noticing :) Another positive aspect: if you feel a little sick, you can still join that online class (no fear of infecting your classmates, no need to move out of the house). Bad facts about online classes: no interaction between you and your friends, asking questions works, but is not personal, biggest point for me is that if your teacher does not stop asking but you need to ask something, interupting him/her seems rude (in class that is way more easy by raising your hand-> teacher notices that immediately). Moreover the internet connection can be bad sometimes. Good part about in-person classes: more contact with other school members (if you don't understand something, you can quickly ask for help from class members sitting next to you). Asking the teacher questions is easier in person, you can even stay after class to ask specific questions! Bad things: teachers see everything you do, how you behalte,... Also, you are way more uncomfortable because of ugly school buildings

column16: Nothing, fortunately my school has trained my teachers so good, so they could use some of  the tools we can find online, from simulators to different softwares. Besides, they’ve always trying to include technological tools to our clases, so we were pretty much used to some softwares we are using now, as zoom and canvas. One thing I like the most about online classes, is that they record the class, so we can re-watch it whenever we want in case we need to, also our teachers are fully set to help even if it is after classes, some of them schedule homework consulting for the ones who may have doubts, and that’s great. I feel my school is a role model because they are using a lot of tools and turning everything that we were supposed to do and experience on campus, online. And I think a lot of schools in Mexico an around the work could learn from each other to make this work the best way.
column17: In-person classes, perhaps my school is doing a great job with online classes, but I feel we need human contact at the end of the day. Also, the way of that the teachers develop the classes in-person are way more engaging than online.

column8: In-class assessments/quizzes, Videos
column16: I understand that professors and lecturers are under a lot of pressure and utterly unprepared for a new situation like this, but I would really appreciate if they would make their content more online friendly. In way too many classes it feels like it's more important to get everything barely covered and rushed through than to actually take the time and teach. I also hope that the classes would be more interactive and engaging, but since I study physics which is a greatly calculus-based subject it's impossible to find a perfect pace and level for everyone especially online.
column17: I don't prefer online classes. I understand why many people do though, and how much more convenient that is in some cases, but as I stated due to my course and classes it is way harder to actually learn when studying online. The online lectures I might still be able to deal with but our learning process includes weakly assingment sets which are supposed and designed to be done in a small group. column16: Some of my lecturers record and put it on this platform called echo360 but one of them puts them up as mp4’s the problem with mp4’s in contrast to echo is that you can’t speed the lecture up. I’m very much a quick learner and being able to listen to lecture on 1.5x or 2x speed is a life changer especially when the lecturer is perhaps a slower talker or whatever.
column17: I don’t mind online classes in fact when there were still in person classes I would often through the years at uni (this is my fifth and final year) watch recorded lectures instead of going to class. However being a law student there is nothing quite like going to class and being surrounded by your peers and having discussions before class, being there physically in front of your lecturer, being able to put your hand up and debate in person with the class, have a lecturer make a joke and hear the laughter of everyone, the incessant coughing of everyone in the winter (which will be looked at a little differently now in light of corona lol), and all sorts of engagement face to face. Video lectures and zoom gets the job done and I’m not super hindered by it however nothing can ever compare to face to face interaction and there are numerous studies that show students learn far better in a face to face environment than they ever will online. There is often a disconnect between typing something up and actually physically writing something as well. I miss actual classes and can’t wait for my uni to return to real classes because so much time is spent online these days it’s ridiculous. Over platforms such as zoom you never fully get the same feeling as actually being there talking to people seeing their body language cues etc. the innovations in technology are amazing but they’re still not there, me video chatting my lecturer will never be the same as in person. I’m thankful every day I have the capability to be at uni so can’t wait to be back surrounded by real people, laughing at lecturers shit jokes and all complaining about our next assignment :)

column16: This depends heavily on the unit as they’re structured completely different from one another. Just having a lecture online is the worst as after maximum 60min my brain just shuts off if there’s no active engagement. Other subjects rely on discussions and happen to be quite fun, others are tutorials and don’t differ much from the person-to-person experience and others are complimentary to recorded lectures and script. If the class is not structured in a way that I have to participate in lecture to be able to get the relevant information I don’t attend as just passively sitting in front of my screen is not helpful at all. I think that this leads to the overall point of: making them more interactive so that staying focused is easier and learning is a more active process
column17: Depends. I prefer small discussion based rounds to be conducted in person as I think our physical presence is crucial for communication but for more fact intake based classes I prefer online as I’m more free in choosing where to study and also when in case of recorded lectures. Furthermore crowded spaces such as lecture halls drain me from energy and online teaching is the perfect way around this.

column8: Q&A with students' questions
column16: Some of our professors just send us pdf’s and tell us what we have to read every day. I don’t think that that’s a good online teaching method: the professors are really absent and everything relies on the students during this really difficult and uncertain situation. There’s a lot of pressure and responsibility on our backs. Also, professors don’t stimulate us to think outside of the box and don’t encourage us neither to express our ideas nor to work in group. Online classes should be a form of debating and active learning instead of being based in memorising and copying.
column17: I definitely prefer in-person classes. Personally, I retain information better when explained verbally, and feel less pressure when it comes to asking questions, participating in class debates and explaining concepts to others. Also, my professors usually give simpler and more understandable lessons in class than via pdf, and make the sessions more dynamic. I also feel it easier to ask my classmates about the lessons when we are at uni than by message. What’s more, I miss the entire environment of the university: studying at home doesn’t feel as important and concerning as going to campus.

column17: No because I do quite a practical subject (medicine) where it’s people based and so some of the skills taught such as history taking is not as effective over the computer. Also I’m more motivated when I have to get ready and go to uni in comparison to opening my laptop. In addition, I enjoy the face to face interaction better with people in small groups/classes/lectures. I am also immensely privileged to have an area away from my family to focus on uni work whereas there are many people on my course who don’t have that privilege, who have to worry about their kids, homes and finding a desk etc. As I mentioned I cannot do many practical skills such as venipuncture etc and if I have a question after the fact it takes longer from them to reply than if I remembered after class and can walk up and speak to them. I think that online classes are missing that one crucial piece, human contact which is not over a screen. However I’m very blessed to be able to still have online classes and be able to still continue the course this way.

column17:
They are a fantastic alternative in the era of corona and I feel so lucky that a) I have access to education b) it can all go online almost seamlessly. BUT I do miss being at university and the environment there. I get sick of looking at screens all day and not changing locations. I find it easier to ask questions to my professors in person. Problem solving activities become more difficult when we can’t use facilities to collaborate. I miss my uni friends! Although we chat via text or zoom meetings- it’s not the same! I miss the fun activities of uni between classes that refreshed and motivated me (omg the volunteering at this not for profit vegan sustainable restaurant and bulk food place on campus is the stuff dreams are made of!). For myself in my course, we have clinical skills tutorials where we learn how to do practical skills in medicine which is almost impossible now (how do I auscultate without equipment or knowing what sounds are relevant when? or how do I practice injections? On myself?? no!), overall I feel lucky that I have this privilege but I do prefer the way the day ran, the academic vibes of campus and the ease of learning and depth of learning in person classes provided
Big love to you Jade I love your go getter, adventurous and driven attitude! good luck with your assignment and hope iso is treating you well!!
